content:
Princeton. We took Princeton.

Two victories in ten days. The men are actually smiling. I forgot what that looked like.
historicalContext: The Battle of Princeton (January 3, 1777) followed Washington's Trenton victory. These back-to-back wins revived American morale.

content:
They flanked us. Again. I don't know how they keep doing this.

We're retreating. Again.
historicalContext: At the Battle of Brandywine, British forces outflanked Washington's army, forcing a retreat and opening the road to Philadelphia.

content:
Heard Philadelphia has fallen. My home. My printing press. My library.

At least I'm safe in Paris. That feels wrong to say.
historicalContext: British forces occupied Philadelphia on September 26, 1777. Franklin was in Paris negotiating French support.

content:
BURGOYNE SURRENDERED. An entire British army! 6,000 of them!

I'm crying. Everyone's crying. Even the general.
historicalContext: British General Burgoyne surrendered his entire army at Saratoga on October 17, 1777. This victory convinced France to ally with America.

content:
Valley Forge. 11,000 men. Half without shoes. It's starting to snow.

They look at me like I have answers. I don't.
historicalContext: The Continental Army entered winter quarters at Valley Forge on December 19, 1777, beginning a brutal winter that tested their resolve.

content:
It's done. France recognizes us. They're sending soldiers. Ships. Money.

I need to sit down. My hands are shaking.
historicalContext: France signed the Treaty of Alliance with the United States on February 6, 1778, formally recognizing American independence.

content:
A Prussian showed up today. Says he was a general. Doesn't speak English. Started drilling my men anyway.

They're learning. Actually learning.
historicalContext: Baron von Steuben arrived at Valley Forge and began transforming the Continental Army through rigorous training.

content:
Monmouth. We held. For the first time we HELD.

The training worked. We're not a mob anymore. We're an army.
historicalContext: The Battle of Monmouth (June 28, 1778) was effectively a draw, but showed the Continental Army could match British regulars in open battle.

content:
The General embraced me on the field. Called me a son. I have never felt more proud.

This is what I came here for. This.
historicalContext: Lafayette distinguished himself at Monmouth and became one of Washington's most trusted officers.

content:
John Paul Jones beat them. BEAT THE BRITISH NAVY. With a ship that was literally sinking.

'I have not yet begun to fight.' Absolute madman.
historicalContext: John Paul Jones defeated HMS Serapis despite his ship Bonhomme Richard being severely damaged. His famous reply when asked to surrender became legend.

content:
Charleston has surrendered. Our entire southern army. Gone.

Three years we've fought. Three years. And still this.
historicalContext: The Siege of Charleston ended with the surrender of over 5,000 American troops - the worst American defeat of the war.

content:
Arnold. Benedict Arnold. My most trusted general.

A traitor. He was going to give them West Point. Give them ME.

I don't have words.
historicalContext: Benedict Arnold's plot to surrender West Point to the British was discovered on September 25, 1780. Arnold escaped to British lines.

content:
Kings Mountain. We won. Just backwoods boys with rifles against trained soldiers.

My brother didn't make it back. But we won.
historicalContext: The Battle of Kings Mountain was a turning point in the South, fought entirely by American militia against Loyalists.

content:
Cowpens. Total victory. Tarleton ran away. THE Tarleton.

The butcher butchered.
historicalContext: At the Battle of Cowpens, Daniel Morgan's forces destroyed Tarleton's Legion in a brilliant tactical victory.

content:
We won at Guilford Courthouse. Technically. A quarter of my army is dead.

Another victory like this will destroy us.
historicalContext: The British 'won' at Guilford Courthouse but suffered 25% casualties. Cornwallis abandoned the Carolinas afterward.

content:
The French fleet is coming. Cornwallis is in Yorktown. We're marching south.

Everything depends on timing now. Everything.
historicalContext: Washington coordinated with French Admiral de Grasse for a combined assault on Cornwallis at Yorktown.

content:
The French fleet has arrived. 28 ships. The British cannot reinforce Cornwallis now.

We have him.
historicalContext: The Battle of the Chesapeake prevented British reinforcement of Cornwallis, sealing his fate at Yorktown.

content:
He surrendered. Cornwallis surrendered.

The band played 'The World Turned Upside Down.' I cannot stop smiling. Six years. Six years.
historicalContext: Cornwallis surrendered at Yorktown on October 19, 1781. The British band allegedly played 'The World Turned Upside Down.'

content:
I just watched a British general surrender his sword. A British GENERAL.

We won. We actually won. I don't know what to do with my hands.
historicalContext: Over 8,000 British troops surrendered at Yorktown. Many Americans struggled to believe the war was essentially over.

content:
The House voted to end offensive operations in America. It's over. We've lost the colonies.

I need to resign. I should have resigned years ago.
historicalContext: Parliament voted to end offensive operations in America in February 1782, effectively ending the war.

content:
Treaty signed. Paris. Britain recognizes American independence.

I was there when we declared it. Now I'm here when they accept it. Seven years.
historicalContext: The Treaty of Paris (September 3, 1783) formally ended the Revolutionary War and recognized American independence.

content:
The last British soldiers left New York today. I watched them go.

We're free. After eight years. We're actually free.
historicalContext: Evacuation Day - British troops left New York City on November 25, 1783, ending eight years of British occupation.

content:
I gave it back. The power, the army, all of it. I'm going home to Martha.

They looked surprised. Why are they surprised? This was always the point.
historicalContext: Washington resigned his commission on December 23, 1783, shocking the world by giving up power voluntarily.
